text: the cold came late that fall and and the
songbirds were caught off guard by the
time the snow and wind began in earnest
too many had been suckered into staying
and instead of flying south
they were huddled in people's yards
their feathers puffed for some modicum
of warms Lori Moore is one of America's
most admired literary writers her short
stories and novels are fixtures on the
bestseller list and rhapsodic Lee
praised by critics across the land
recently Lori Moore visited The Times
and we talked about her new novel a gate
at the stairs and also about the 25
years she has spent living it in Madison
Wisconsin a part of the Midwest that
Easterners and Westerners often see only
from the window of an airplane as they
travel from one coast to the other Lori
Moore a new novel a gate at the stairs
published a rapturous reviews including
in the book review you're on the
bestseller list how does it feel it's
been what 15 years since your last novel
came out it's been 15 years I wanted to
sort of scoop up everything I thought
was sort of interesting about Madison
and Wisconsin and a university town in
the countryside outside of it have you
been hearing from Wisconsin readers here
now
oh I have and some are unhappy do they
think you're satirizing them some are
unhappy you know there are a lot of
people you know for instance in The
Times review there was a the use of the
word fly over and Midwesterners don't
like that and so then they've they and
I've used it myself in fiction I I used
the word fly over but I've become enough
of a Midwestern ER where I you know I
can be if I can understand the offense
of that and and when someone else uses
it I'd start to bristle myself except I
use it all the time
how did you find your heroine were you
in the front of a classroom or walking
that lovely campus one day and saw
someone who might be Tassie or your
narrator that's a very interesting
thought I've never know I've never seen
anyone who might be heard she's in my
mind very clearly but I've never seen
anyone in the real world that was her
and so I so I felt I had to kind of
create her and keep company with her and
she is a sort of every woman sensibility
to some extent given the specifics of
her background in circumstances but I I
was I felt very close to her for very
many years so it was hard to hard to
give the book up and to some extent how
many years was it well it was off and on
off and on for about ten years did you
begin the novel then before September
11th I started with Tassie a little bit
before before 9/11 because 9/11 forms
much of the atmosphere and backdrop it
was to write the novel didn't really
settle into what year was going to be in
until until later now you're also
substantial often quite brilliant
literary critic when you write about
other fiction writers do you then become
professor Moore are you still the
empathetic novelist you and have at the
skin of the the novelists you're right
about try to figure out how they're
doing why they're doing what they do
sometimes sometimes so when you do a
review you get to sort of look back over
the previous books and you get to sort
of take a little course in that author
and then write a kind of paper who's a
writer exceedingly different from
yourself whom you admire but no you
could never be Oh sort of opposite
writer of Laura oh well I I oh yeah it's
the same answer for who do I admire I
always say Alice Munro I think of her as
writing very differently from me and I
could never do what she does but I just
love what she does I'm in
do you have any idea who your diverse
readers are they women or the man
everybody I feel their boss I mean I

assume my readers are mostly women but I
I think they're both I don't know I

it's been 70% pretty constant through
